data.text: @chadinabhan @ASH_hematology @AaronGoodman33 @VincentRK Love it!

RT @chadinabhan: Right here at @ASH_hematology #ASH22 with @AaronGoodman33 & @VincentRK discussing science, mentorship, and music. 

Great…

@bdermanmd Right, but with that analysis you select for a fitter population and forego the benefits of randomization. It’s not a fair comparison anyways. For a fit motivated older patient who strongly values PFS, a transplant is reasonable.
@strouse_chris @AaronGoodman33 @nihardesai7 I’m in same boat Chris!

@KonLontos @AaronGoodman33 I agree with waiting for full data. At some combination of age and frailty, this “some point down the road” becomes an unrealistic fantasy though. Further down the road, other therapies will also mature and be available.
@Balitsky_HemeMD @HiraSMian Superstar indeed!
@nihardesai7 @AaronGoodman33 Trial enrolled a long time ago- 2009 was when it was first listed on the European trial registry

@HematoRules Hi- this trial enrolled long before the MAIA trial (dara/len/dex). 

However if anything the relative benefit offered by a transplant would be even less compared to dara/len/dex or velcade/len/dex.

Excited to moderate this session at #ASH22 at 4:00 pm tomorrow! Look forward to a robust discussion. 

#mmsm https://t.co/GUZumDyEVs

I speak only for myself here- I recognize everyone has strong opinions about this. I meet patients according to their values/preferences- it is a nuanced discussion. Look forward to further discussion at the meeting.

⭐️Practice changing abstract

⭐️Mel140 fails to beat len/dex in 60-75 year olds

This combined with lack of OS benefit to date in DETERMINATION/IFM 2009 has considerably lessened enthusiasm to transpl (esp mel140) standard risk #mmsm above age 70.

#ASH22
https://t.co/9NykX99A65

data.text:
Heading to NOLA shortly for #ASH22 but getting some runs in before heading to the airport!
#lifeelevated @UofUHealth https://t.co/R2MfQxjFMs
A very thoughtful thread by @HadidiSamer on smoldering MM. #mmsm https://t.co/NsSIACnhVI
@CoachBon Coach Bonnie- I will write more about this after attending the presentation. I need to understand it better. Will keep you updated.
RT @JuliPerezBot: Getting excited for #ASH22 Check out the preview issue by our amazing ASH New Daily crew! ⁦@ASH_hematology⁩ ⁦@n_gangat⁩ ⁦…
@RitaAssi4 @doctorpemm @Mohty_EBMT @Dr_AmerZeidan Sorry you couldn’t make it! Will try my best to keep you updated (especially since you put my name up there with the legends!)

@kansagraMD And I appreciate you sharing this table- but a more relevant comparison is this:

MRD neg rates post-ASCT in GEM-CESAR= 63%
MRD neg rates post-ASCT in KRD arm of FORTE=83%.

I will humbly admit that I am surprised and disappointed.
@Eddie_Cliff @dgermain21 Can’t wait to see you again Eddie!

@kansagraMD I do think the MRD negativity rates were much lower than expected. The thought process presumably was that it’s earlier stage, and hence theoretically easier to “eradicate/nip it in the bud”. Will inquire further at the meeting, look forward to discussing.
@mattjbrunner One can argue that a similar (if not higher) ballpark percentage of patients with myeloma can be cured with todays therapies/available agents as well.
I would really love if someone with more expertise in #mmsm than me, would thoughtful engage on this thread- and offer their thoughts. Look forward to discussing at ASH as well.

Which is why the very low rates of sustained MRD negativity rates (23% on intent to treat) with an aggressive approach of KRD>transplant> maintenance is so troubling.

#mmsm #ASH22

https://t.co/2x1vesjxNo https://t.co/rpUH4UYKFX

data.text: @BijoyTelivala @VincentRK @myelomaMD From a "prognostic" standpoint, outcomes similar whether you progress on 10mg of len or 25mg or len. I do not think this study answers the utility of a dose escalation of lenalidomide. Anecdotally, that can sometimes buy additional time, but I do not know or good evidence for it.
@HemSandoval @VincentRK @myelomaMD I meant *study*, not trial :)
@HemSandoval @VincentRK @myelomaMD This trial doesnt necessarily answer that question specifically. It is thought provoking though.

urls.title: Outcomes of Multiple Myeloma Patients Refractory to Standard Dose Vs Low Dose Lenalidomide
urls.description: Background: Lenalidomide (Len) containing regimens are extensively used as first line therapy in multiple myeloma (MM). Since most patients (pts) eventually rel

data.text:
Useful abstract by @VincentRK @myelomaMD seems to indicate that lenalidomide refractoriness is not a dose dependent (len 10mg vs 25mg) phenomena.

Subsequent outcomes similar whether progressing on low dose of len or full dose of len. 

https://t.co/D2NFxIs6a7

#ASH22 
#mmsm

@MichaelJSlade @CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @VincentRK @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy And to answer your Q, this year I reviewed abstracts/ served on ASH News team- so spent a lot of time scrolling through oral/poster sessions for various diseases. As I am a clinician, I rely on others to inform me about relevant basic research, and focus energy on clinical stuff.

@MichaelJSlade @CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @VincentRK @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy Theres great advice already given here by people smarter than me.

Most importantly, reassure yourself that something truly practice changing will find your attention through news/conversations/twitter. You wont miss it. I recommend focusing on networking/socializing/having fun😀
@HiraSMian I have full day clinic tomorrow too! 🙁
RT @psharmaMD: @ManniMD1 @iStopMM @sykristinsson Very nice! We are changing practice in Utah for sure :). I gave a short 15 mins talk to PC…

@AJurczyszyn @AaronGoodman33 @iStopMM @sykristinsson I will email you after ASH as well. Please do DM me your email. And if you are at ASH, would love to meet!

Thanks

@sykristinsson @AaronGoodman33 @iStopMM @ingigerdursv I wish this was an oral session, but I will be sure to drop by and give a shout-out to @ingigerdursv's poster, its one of the most practice informing/changing sessions at this entire meeting.
@AaronGoodman33 @iStopMM @sykristinsson I will send after the ASH meeting, as @sykristinsson was kind enough to share some confidential slides that I used. I will share after the meeting 😀

data.text:
Perhaps my favorite #mmsm disparity research at #ASH22.

Rather than comparing outcomes between races in another dataset, or describing low enrollment in trials, this study helps us understand the “why” of the story.

https://t.co/QJR4sU8GvB

@ShakiraG_MBBS @stuchman1 https://t.co/aw10T0N8qj

The presence or absence of gain1q did not change outcomes in a cohort of patients with relapsed myeloma receiving daratumumab- data from the Mayo dataset.

IMO- Anti-CD38 therapy similarly effective in gain1q, whether you choose isa or dara. 

https://t.co/hMfWRSn6tN

#ASH22

data.text: @RahulDoc2 Thanks for your reply on this tweet- that truly is a tough situation, hopefully you will find the information from the abstract useful during the consent process.

Good reminder of limited role of allogenic transplant in multiple myeloma- Mayo Clinic experience

N=89
Long term survival in less than 20%
By 2 years, 75% pts either progressed or died

Caveat:most patients at relapse, not 1st remission

https://t.co/TRmA2IIBMa

#mmsm 
#ASH22 https://t.co/KDYAfJRqgU

data.text: @sykristinsson @iStopMM @asdisrosa78 @SigrunThorstei1 @ThorvardurL @thorirlong @eliaseythorsson @SaemundurMD @PalmasonRobert @jthorir @astrunhelga @ingigerdursv So inspirational, Sigurdur! Look forward to seeing you at ASH.

RT @sykristinsson: The @iStopMM team is very excited to present our findings at #ASH22

Presentations from the study are, like before, prim…
@rajshekharucms @mtmdphd Thank you Raj for your kind words and for sharing!
@KRakszawski May the force be with you!

@BijoyTelivala @VincentRK Yes, but DRd (MAIA) was studied in transplant ineligible patients. We don’t have robust data on DRd for transplant eligible patients. The data for quads in “transplant eligible” is stronger (with limitations of surrogates) than the data for DRd.

@VincentRK Dr Rajkumar, could you explain the thought process behind including DRd (but not D-RVD) for newly diagnosed standard risk MM?

Appreciate it.

@VincentRK @EhsanMalekMD @AaronGoodman33 @SagarLonialMD @End_myeloma I appreciate your reply Dr Rajkumar! Thank you. Do you have more information on the characteristics of these renal events in the control arm? Level of creatinine elevation. Did anyone end up on dialysis? Did they recover with initiation of myeloma treatment? Would be useful info.

You were right @AaronGoodman33 

The DM was pure optics- nothing productive came out of it. @Optum took the weekend off, while our patients with cancer stayed in a limbo about whether their necessary treatment would be approved or not. https://t.co/WtFwkcYCg1

#ASH22 starts this week.

Here is a list of top 10 abstracts that have already influenced my thought and practice in myeloma! Look forward to hearing more about these and other studies at the meeting!

#mmsm https://t.co/mmiGmXbiUG
@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 Also, I am nowhere near the level of expertise of the other people you’ve asked such as Dr Lonial, so take what I say with a grain of salt.

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 Ultimately, it is a complex nuanced decision, but there is enough ambiguity here that observing without treatment is a fully appropriate decision that I support when my patients make it. 3/end

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 Data from the German group highlighted in a recent thread I shared indicates that renal failure and compression fractures in absence of preceding lytic lesions are rare. Providing this information provides reassurance to my patients and I try to mention. 2/

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 It is tough to answer this w nuance on twitter. In general, depends on patient values/preferences. Every single time, when I’ve seen a high risk SMM and discussed data on len, they’ve elected to observe. 

There is a 2/20/20+cytogenetics model, but also with same limitations. 1/

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 @DrOlaLandgren @RnInfection - hopefully this paper (and thread to explain it) will provide you with some reassurance.

https://t.co/EgYLWdLBjS

Highlights the power of mentorship in an inter-connected global era, where a lot of it can be done remotely! Kudos to all these trainees.

Thanks for reading! Look forward to seeing you soon at #ASH22.

END.

5. There is only one poster that I present myself (on the role of anti-CD38 therapy in 11;14 myeloma), meet me at that Session in Hall D on Saturday 5:30 pm . Manuscript already accepted at Blood Cancer Journal, I will share a thread soon!

https://t.co/AVYiHqpdgd

Also, if you are a trainee- my DM's are open- would love to meet you!

urls.description: At a live virtual event, Sumit Madan, MD, broke down the use of quadruplet therapies in the frontline setting for patients with multiple myeloma and how to care for patients when they relapse on treatment.

data.text:
Is it fair for us to politely ask (without disrespecting the people being interviewed) who pays @TargetedOnc for this content?

Is it fair to ask them to report money they received from Karyopharm (if any) for this?

https://t.co/lY1whIeggs

@MyelomaAmateur @CoachBon I also must clarify that I was not proposing clinical trial enrollment to be a passive process, and to have interpreted my original tweet as that is an unfortunate misrepresentation of my original intent. Thank you @CoachBon and @MyelomaAmateur for calling a spade a spade.
@KFHemeOnc @AdiG1993 @nihardesai7 @AaronGoodman33 You are very kind- thank you!

@HadidiSamer I think nuance will be lost describing the process on twitter unfortunately. It will be tough. 

I was never able to successfully consent anybody for belantamab in newly diagnosed myeloma either. 🙁
@GuiperiniMD Appreciate your input and sharing that. I don’t think you are “correcting” something wrong I have said, but you context is helpful.

Those with intermediate risk smoldering myeloma according to 2/20/20 have a 18% chance of progression at 2 years.

Should they be enrolled in a single arm small (n=15) trial of a drug with a much higher likelihood of severe toxicity (relative to risk of progression)?

#mmsm https://t.co/F51Xc7ZuI3

RT @HadidiSamer: Another day, another single arm study in smoldering myeloma. Now with Selinexor with extension to intermediate risk SMM
Wh…

@ClayReedMD @JackWestMD @AaronGoodman33 You’re very kind. Sounds hard to believe but I try to not get embroiled in too much controversy here.

To answer your question- Foremost is @oncology_bg. Must follow.
RT @MorieGertz: Note FLCr>100 even with proteinuria had median time to myeloma of over 3 years. How is this a myeloma defining event where…

@AaronGoodman33 What is the number needed to treat to prevent one fracture (or kidney injury that does not reverse)?

Would be interested to know, just not known from data.

RT @CyclingDoctor: Sobering (but not surprising) results of the ASCO Survey regarding prior authorization.
@AaronGoodman33 @ManniMD1 @Rahul…
@Optum It’s an inconvenience and harm to our patients foremost. I will DM details
@AfafOsman7 @BloodAdvances Congrats Afaf!

@BrunoPaiva_UNAV Look forward to discussing in person at ASH!

@CoachBon @TMSchmidtMD @RahulBanerjeeMD @MeeraMohanMD @HadidiSamer Hi Coach Bonnie- the entire paper is covered in a snapshot picture of the first tweet of this thread. Please DM me and I can email you a PDF too.

@AaronGoodman33 As you and I pointed out in our paper (here’s the thread for that paper):

 https://t.co/SERddRh414

@AaronGoodman33 I do think there is merit to 1-2 such studies and I commend this group for trying this intervention. Worth seeing if patients were cured by this approach. However why would studying a different 3 or 4 drug combo (as is done in many single-arm studies) lead to different results?

data.text:
Amongst most profound observations from #ASH22 

If sustained MRD neg is best surrogate for cure, note that aggressive attempt to "cure" smoldering MM using KRD>trans>maintenance led to only 23% sustained MRD neg.

Immense implications for smoldering MM/early intervention.

#mmsm https://t.co/EK29OHpfAG

@amirsali101 Thanks for reading and sharing. Hope to meet you in person at ASH

#mmsm

https://t.co/TUXXrgf4Xy

Patients and health care professionals deserve honest, unbiased reporting! https://t.co/56kwy3t1AT

urls.title: Reporting of trials with possible detrimental overall survival: a patient advocate perspective
urls.description: On Oct 22, 2021, melflufen, a novel peptide–drug conjugate intended for use in relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma, was withdrawn from the US market by the pharmaceutical company that developed it, Oncopeptides, on the basis of possible detrimental overall survival in the group that received melflufen in its confirmatory OCEAN trial. Only a month earlier—and despite an existing US Food and Drug Administration hold due to an increased number of patient deaths in the melflufen group—the same trial had received positive coverage when it was presented at the International Myeloma Workshop (IMW; Sept 8–11, 2021, in Vienna, Austria).

data.text:
I owe gratitude to @MyelomaAmateur, a patient advocate who inspired us to do this.

I published this article with her in @TheLancetHaem on how oncology news media reported on a drug that improved PFS but worsened OS:

https://t.co/j2mmSrPPL5

#mmsm

tweets.text: Getting excited for #ASH22 Check out the preview issue by our amazing ASH New Daily crew! ⁦@ASH_hematology⁩ ⁦@n_gangat⁩ ⁦@ManniMD1⁩ ⁦@mlblack1_b⁩  https://t.co/UI495cTIsx

Unable to attend #ASH2022 in person; but relying on some amazing tweeters to get the gist while virtually attending as much as I can
@doctorpemm @Mohty_EBMT @Dr_AmerZeidan @ManniMD1 and many many others!

@ManniMD1 Are we surprised that MRD rate is low ? If you look at quad therapies  MRD rates! Did we expect SMM (idk pop, but eg high risk) will have significant high MRF rates ? 

Not proposing for KRD/Tx/Main as Rx but realizing what shld we expect from SMM fully loaded Rx options https://t.co/BmgDLN7aDQ

Survived my first Southwest airlines boarding experience (no allocated seats!) and now en route to NOLA for #ASH22 after a lovely stopover visiting the fab @dgermain21 in St Louis! See you soon fellow haem nerds 🥳🩸 https://t.co/H2nCrg8tNW

@ManniMD1 Too early to say. If 20% are truly long term cured, then certainly would be promising, particularly for person <60yo with high risk SMM. If everyone eventually relapses, then it’s not a paradigm shift and best we could hope for is incremental progress.

Which is why the very low rates of sustained MRD negativity rates (23% on intent to treat) with an aggressive approach of KRD>transplant> maintenance is so troubling.

#mmsm #ASH22

https://t.co/2x1vesjxNo https://t.co/rpUH4UYKFX

tweets.text: I love the fact that this is a fixed duration study and explores MRD. I believe curing a disease requires eradication at the molecular level. Trials will determine that. #ASH22 @ASH_hematology https://t.co/b6P5onvY5g
@ManniMD1 @VincentRK @myelomaMD if thats the case why do some people consider inc the dose of Len from 10 to 15 mg in the maintiance setting ?
@HemSandoval @VincentRK @myelomaMD This trial doesnt necessarily answer that question specifically. It is thought provoking though.
@ManniMD1 @VincentRK @myelomaMD So the strategy of increasing len dose from 10 to 25 mg on a pt that is having biochemical while Len maintenance is probably not useful?. Very good study!

@MichaelJSlade @CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @VincentRK @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy Theres great advice already given here by people smarter than me.

Most importantly, reassure yourself that something truly practice changing will find your attention through news/conversations/twitter. You wont miss it. I recommend focusing on networking/socializing/having fun😀

As a trainee who’s overwhelmed by the volume of abstracts for #ASH2022, any advice on filtering/reviewing/scheduling from the senior folks?

@CyclingDoctor @LabFehniger @DiPersioLab @AaronGoodman33 @ManniMD1 @DavidSteensma @bdermanmd @VPrasadMDMPH @VincentRK @myelomaMD @Geoff_Uy

@PallawiTorkaMD @PrashantTembha1 @DrRahulBhargav1 @Prasshmehta @DrSwami_Iyer @NitinJainMD @BldCancerDoc 😭😭 Would have loved to connect. Will definitely see you at #ASH2023 😍

See you in New Orleans! https://t.co/UdAS2UvU8m

Attempting to get my email inbox to zero before #ASH22 - it currently sits at 916.

@ManniMD1 @VincentRK Wasn’t GRIFFIN an open label Phase 2 vs RCT and Phase 3 

Does that explain it ?
Ahead of #ASH22 here are my updated algorithms for current treatment of myeloma. https://t.co/xj2USXFneM

@EhsanMalekMD @ManniMD1 @AaronGoodman33 @SagarLonialMD @End_myeloma We don’t make guidelines for the US only. In most countries Len is $100 per month or less. And once patent problems end in a couple years we will have Len at that price here as well.
@ManniMD1 @Optum The DM won’t help.  I did this before with another company. I promise it is just so they look good

I am excited to be on the @ASH_hematology News Daily editorial board, and will be covering/attending the meeting this year.

In this 🧵, I will highlight the top 10 myeloma abstracts that most influence my thought and practice from the #ASH22 meeting!  

#mmsm

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 Ultimately, it is a complex nuanced decision, but there is enough ambiguity here that observing without treatment is a fully appropriate decision that I support when my patients make it. 3/end

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 Data from the German group highlighted in a recent thread I shared indicates that renal failure and compression fractures in absence of preceding lytic lesions are rare. Providing this information provides reassurance to my patients and I try to mention. 2/

@RnInfection @AaronGoodman33 It is tough to answer this w nuance on twitter. In general, depends on patient values/preferences. Every single time, when I’ve seen a high risk SMM and discussed data on len, they’ve elected to observe. 

There is a 2/20/20+cytogenetics model, but also with same limitations. 1/

@ManniMD1 @AaronGoodman33 I asked Dr. Lonial if they do early intervention on all HRSMM pts or are there parameters to further define HR? No two patients are alike and I struggle with the 2-20-20 definition, especially in the absence of any sign of CRAB and standard genetics. https://t.co/DI9GkSqmnV

How do patients with smoldering myeloma progress? Is it fracture appearing suddenly without corresponding lesions first seen on serial imaging?
Is it sudden renal failure?

An excellent study from Germany in which patients were prospectively observed provides insight

A 🧵

#mmsm

@ManniMD1 @AaronGoodman33 Surely close monitoring for CRAB will reveal progression well before irreversible KD or fractures, even if one pushes into the 2-20-20 high risk? I assume renal failure/fractures don't happen overnight? Looking forward to my appt post BMB with my MM specialist @DrOlaLandgren

5. There is only one poster that I present myself (on the role of anti-CD38 therapy in 11;14 myeloma), meet me at that Session in Hall D on Saturday 5:30 pm . Manuscript already accepted at Blood Cancer Journal, I will share a thread soon!

https://t.co/AVYiHqpdgd

@CoachBon @ManniMD1 This is connected to what I was trying to say yesterday. I absolutely don't want a return to paternalism in medicine, & patients should be involved in making tx decisions  but is it honestly in any pt's best interest to enroll on this study? 🤔
@AdiG1993 @nihardesai7 @AaronGoodman33 Don't forget the great @ManniMD1!
@ManniMD1 I am interested to know how @ManniMD1  you can do an informed consent to enrol in such study?

Another day, another single arm study in smoldering myeloma. Now with Selinexor with extension to intermediate risk SMM
Why do we need this? #mmsm 
✅How can this be helpful to pts?
✅How can this be helpful to field?
Will it be possible to stop doing such studies please?! https://t.co/fl1ickDOLu

Anyone have any additional recommendations to follow for solid tumors (similar to @JackWestMD, @AaronGoodman33, @ManniMD1)?  People who are a little more critical and not afraid to be controversial. #MedTwitter #Oncology.
Note FLCr>100 even with proteinuria had median time to myeloma of over 3 years. How is this a myeloma defining event where expected should be 80%@2 years

I have been told it cruel to observe smoldering myeloma as patients will develop broken hips and backs.  I don't want this to happen!  

Show me data treating prevents this (as opposed to PET+ bone lesion or Hb 10) and I will be glad to start treating smoldering myeloma.
@ManniMD1 We regret the inconvenience this issue has caused, Manni. If you'd like to speak to someone regarding your concerns, please private message us your name and phone number. Thank you

@ManniMD1 Maybe one such study with very very careful consent.  After that we need know more.
Asymptomatic patients are dying on single arm treatment studies of smoldering myeloma. We need to stop doing this. https://t.co/bVkD30HCBL

Amongst most profound observations from #ASH22 

If sustained MRD neg is best surrogate for cure, note that aggressive attempt to "cure" smoldering MM using KRD>trans>maintenance led to only 23% sustained MRD neg.

Immense implications for smoldering MM/early intervention.
